title.narrative: 2.2.1 Grant making - strategic resourcing to community organizations in four countries

description.narrative: 2.2.1 Strategic resourcing to enable community organizations working on violence faced by LBT*people and sex workers to undertake emergency assistance, security preparedness and develop long term security solutions

title.narrative: 2.3.2 Number of grants, activists/organisations and amount disbursed

comment.narrative: UHAI has a deep body of work and our activities have a long history. This project is useful to continue the work and venture into new phases for these activities. Therefore, it is complex and difficult to assign a baseline to it.

These were the number of grants made and the number of organisations resourced to implement interventions on violence against Lesbian,Bisexual and Queer women, transgender individuals and female sex workers.

This includes support through two grants; a capacity support grant to an LBQ group in Kenya and a peer grant to a sex worker organisation in Zanzibar . Both grants are reported for using the time of their contracting.
This is the number of organisations supported through 3 grants in this quarter.
This is the number of organisations supported through 3 grants in this quarter.
We supported 4 organisations in 2020 through 3 opportunity grants, and one cost extension.

title.narrative: 2 - ALL women are able to enjoy freedom and opportunities by being able to access and assert their rights to public spaces and resources
O2.2 Number of people that integrate, centre and implement comprehensive long-term solutions to end VAW

comment.narrative: Support to a tanzanian organisation through our peer grant built the capacity of 389 female sex workers on matters legal, health and entrepreneurship as a way of shifting their violence dynamic . through building their negotiating power, and agency in negotiating access to justice and a better appreciation of their health needs. It also included 59 LBQ women in Thika a town on the outskirt of Nairobi whose capacity to institutionally programme around violence was improved through strengthening their systems and structures and mapping strategies. They were also able to train 20 LBQ women as first responders, involved 5 LBQ women in their mapping experiences of violence.

This is the number reached through programming supported in the grants made in this period including in person training, participation in an international advocacy platform and through community radio.
This is the number reached through the programming supported in the grants made in this reporting period.

This number includes female sex workers in Uganda and Kenya that would be contacted through support in the 4 peer grants made and contracted in the first quarter. It also includes numbers achieved through running grants including: three peer grants to LBQ and sex groups in informal urban settlements in metropolitan Kampala, in Uganda, rural Kisumu in Kenya and Nakuru. As well as legal aid through a mainstream organisation in Kampala but with a national reach and violence .programming in the rural post-conflict Northern Uganda.

We awarded four grants (three opportunity grants and one cost extension) in 2020. The support to 175 beneficiaries from the four organisations that included violence response, legal aid, and emergency support during the COVID-19 pandemic period.
